title: 114_s1998
content: The Act is titled the "Creating Higher Education Affordability Necessary to Compete Economically Act" or the "Middle Class CHANCE Act." It aims to increase the maximum amount of a Federal Pell Grant. Section 401(b)(7)(C) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to update clauses and headings for award years 2015-2016 and 2016-2017. For award years 2016-2017 and beyond, the amount determined for Federal Pell Grants is calculated based on a specified formula, with adjustments made for the maximum grant eligibility. Clause (iv) is updated for subsequent award years starting from 2017-2018. For award years 2017-2018 and beyond, the amount for Federal Pell Grants is calculated based on a formula with adjustments for maximum grant eligibility. The amount is increased annually by a percentage and rounded to the nearest $5. YEAR-ROUND FEDERAL PELL GRANT STUDENTS. The amendment to the Higher Education Act of 1965 defines an eligible student as someone who has received a Federal Pell Grant, continues to meet eligibility requirements, and attends an institution of higher education at least half-time. The Secretary is required to award an additional Pell Grant for additional payment periods during an award year. The Higher Education Act of 1965 defines an eligible student as someone who has received a Federal Pell Grant and attends an institution of higher education at least half-time. The Secretary is required to award additional Pell Grants for payment periods not fully covered by the student's initial grant. If a student receives multiple Pell Grants in a year, the total amount cannot exceed 150 percent of the maximum grant. Any period covered by a Pell Grant counts towards the student's duration limit. If a payment period spans two award years, the institution must be allowed to disburse the grant. The amendment allows the institution to determine the award year for additional period. Effective July 1, 2015. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to extend the Pell Grant duration limit from 12 to 15 semesters.
